page.title: 15TERLING LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: The name Terling comes from the old English -Terlinges- meaning "Tyrhtel's People", and has been spelt in many different ways over the years:_ Terlinga, Terlinces, Thirlengs, Therlyng, Tharlinges, Therlyng, Terdling, Torling and Tarling. There has been a settlement here since the Iron Age, and we know that the Romans were here, because a hoard of Roman treasure was found in 1824. The Saxons were here, and Terling is mentioned in the Domesday Book, when the population was only 125. The Manor of Terling was owned by the Bishop of Norwich, who built his Palace here, and later exchanged it with Henry VIII for the Monastery of St.Benet de Hulme. It was a Royal Manor for 2years before it was given to Henry's Lord Chancellor, Thomas Audley. There's proof that Henry VIII came here several times.
